Bassman

Here in Western New York, a major cold front came barrelling through here bringing with it 45 mph winds with 60+mph gusts. Why am I opening this thread with a weather report? Simple. ALL OF THE SCHOOLS WERE CLOSED!!!:xbanghead  When I went to school, a windy day never sopped us from attending. It just frosts me, being the father of a three-year-old, to see just how low we as a nation have become. With the advent of more media options via computer, television, and so forth; many children aren't outside playing. Also, with the farce known as forced bussing, we see children being picked up a few blocks away from their schools. Bill Cosby said it best in this:"...I walked to school in five feet of snow. Uphill. Both ways."

post_info.post_title: Are children far too spoiled in this day and age?

Ooaman

Here in Western New York, a major cold front came barrelling through here bringing with it 45 mph winds with 60+mph gusts. Why am I opening this thread with a weather report? Simple. ALL OF THE SCHOOLS WERE CLOSED!!!:xbanghead  When I went to school, a windy day never sopped us from attending. It just frosts me, being the father of a three-year-old, to see just how low we as a nation have become. With the advent of more media options via computer, television, and so forth; many children aren't outside playing. Also, with the farce known as forced bussing, we see children being picked up a few blocks away from their schools. Bill Cosby said it best in this:"...I walked to school in five feet of snow. Uphill. Both ways."

 Didn't a blizzard just go through New York 1-2 days ago? Do any of (if not all) the schools have any power outages? Could something have gotten into the water supply or something like that? I'm just wanting to make sure you know For A Fact that the schools closed due to some what high wind gust.
 
 I remember when I was a Senior in high school, on a perfectly clear day in April in Eastern Kansas, 3 of the 5 high schools (and various elementary and middle schools) let out. Why? There was a water main break that morning. They got it fixed but by 9:00, they decided that the water was unfit for drinking out of the fountain (more so than usual) and bad for cooking (for the lunches) and various other things.
 
 I used this example because it was a legitimate reason that had nothing to do with the weather.
 
 Basically, do you know for a fact that it was due to high wind?
daewoo

Is closing schools due ot high winds in the winter necesarily a bad thing? Here they generally close schools if the wind chill is below -30 (f). A lot fo kids walk to school, or have to stand around waiting for a bus. We cant have the little bastards catching frost bite on their way to learn to be delenquents.
Cheesejoff
Are you being far too general? If you mean walking to school in the snow, then it's hardly "spoiling" them if they don't have to do it.
snakespit

I actually walked about 2 miles to elementary school when I was a kid. I remember walking to school on days when the temperature was below 20F, and probably walked to school in temperatures much colder than that. If you have ever seen the movie "A Christmas Story", you have an idea of how I was dressed for my walk. The most direct route was through a town park with 3 baseball fields, a community pool, and several large recreation fields in the middle. Along the south side of this park was a small creek. This creek was normally a tame trickle, but I can recall times where the creek rose and flooded just about the entire park. It was not unusual for some of us to show up at school with our pants wet to the knees. Many people from my area of town who had to walk to school had the choice of either walking through the park, or going around it, which added probably at least another half mile to the walk. I would guess that approximately 40 of us used that park every day to and from school. The one thing I never actually got was that about 2 blocks away from my house (and 2 blocks closer to school) there was a bus stop that picked up kids from that street. However, Myself and many living on my street (farther from the school) were not eligible for the bus...go figure.
 
 We used to walk to school in all kinds of weather, cold, rain, wind, etc. We even used to go to school when they were predicting major snow storms. They would let us out only after it started snowing, forcing those of us "walkers" to walk home in a snow storm. And yes, buses used to drive in the snow as well. Now, probably due to peoples willingness to sue everyone over everything, it seems that kids get the day off school if they are predicting even a dusting of snow. I guess you can't be overly cautious. 
 
 Looking back on all of it, I guess I got great exercise, although I probalby could have done without the freezing cold days and driving rains that forced me to sit through the first 4 hours of school sopping wet. Are kids spoiled these days...I guess that is a matter of perspective.
Bassman

Didn't a blizzard just go through New York 1-2 days ago? Do any of (if not all) the schools have any power outages? Could something have gotten into the water supply or something like that? I'm just wanting to make sure you know For A Fact that the schools closed due to some what high wind gust.

 The blizzard you refer to hit Downstate New York, not upstate, where I live. Be that as it may, the schools in NYC didn't close. And yes, the schools closed because of the wind.
simone

Whose children?
 
 And, what do you mean by spoiled?
 
 Assuredly, I walked to and from school through horrific wind chill factors and blizzards (and actually loved it--acting out a desperate Nanook of the North saga) in old Dakota but I was used to it. Does it count if it was only one-quarter of a mile? But, I did not sit in front of a TV all day in a nice warm house. Even the schoolhouse was not especially warm if a fierce wind was blowing.
 
 But, that was then, when kids were tough and mean, and this is now.
simone
I must also add that I walked through a windswept plain with nothing to stop the wind. If I had been tall for my age I might have gotten blown away.
nimthecat

I live in England and my grammar school was closed once because there was heavy snow and the buses couldn't run. About 50 kids who got dropped off by their parents turned up but they were sent home anyway cause so many couldn't attend.
 
 I don't think that's spoiling children, it's keeping their feet firmly on ground - literally! Hahahaha (had to say it).
Matthew S

Uphill. Both ways."

 
 
 Ever seen Dana Carvey's SNL character Grumpy old man? http://snl.jt.org/char.php?i=246 This is what your post reminds me of. But to the point yes children are very spoiled today. Yes their parents are to blame.
georged

Many states now have legislation banning employment of anyone under 16-yrs, lengthening dependency on full parental support. Liability concerns have removed opportunity for children and teens to pursue traditional money making pursuits such as gardening, lawn trimming, newspaper delivery, cleanup and other menial work. I'd think it would be difficult to instill a work ethic and the desire to advance one's self through education or learning a trade in someone beginning at age 16.
Alan Ryan

I understand 'spoiling' children to mean setting no limit to their capricious behaviour. 
 
 Keeping them home from school when it snows, is just a reflection of parental anxiety or perhaps laziness.
jim's trucking

I perceive this thread as questioning whether canceling school because of wind constitutes spoiling as opposed to the more open question expressed literally in the thread title.
 
 I'll go beyond closing schools for bad weather to the question of, 'Are children far too spoiled in this day and age?'
 
 Definitely YES! Not all of them are being spoiled because not all of their parents can afford to do so. 
 
 From the filthy rich to the barely above poverty level, parents are spoiling their children....especially in this day and age, with CARS. Children (and I do mean CHILDREN) are being given light-weight 200 horsepower road rockets to keep them in the popularity races that go on everywhere. This (the big car giveaway) doesn't appear to happen as much within the big cities where sometimes even the parents don't use cars much, but it is rampant in the suburbs and in smaller metros and rural areas. Children are killing and being killed because of their prematurely awarded driving privileges and their 'own' cars.
 
 Children are being spoiled in being allowed to determine their own food intake. That's been happening for a long time, too.
 
 Children are being spoiled in the clothing area. Again, popularity is at stake.
 
 Children are given entirely too much. What they should be given are lessons in working for pay that can be spent as they please. That's what a capitalist environment is about.
 
 I was given too much as a child and I'm betting that most of us were, regardless of when we were children. This day and age, the gifts are more dangerous.
 
 Incidently, my dad used to walk to school barefooted in the snow, shootin' wildcats on the way.
Ian

Children are killing and being killed because of their prematurely awarded driving privileges and their 'own' cars.
 

 
 I completely agree with this. Children take for granted whats already theirs and are more reckless because of it. If it was their parent's cars they wouldn't be so careless due to the fact that the parents would kill the kids for recking their car.
 
 As for the excuses for not having school... My school is a pain in the :xcensored . Our superintendent won't have a snow day even when all the surrounding citys, even the entire county, has a snow day.
zachvac

Well I don't know about NYC, but we just had 50 MPH winds the other day. We still had school AND baseball practice. The wind was blowing over the L-screen (the screen in front of the pitcher so he doesn't get killed) and it was just really really windy. I don't see how wind (unless it's like a tornado) could cancel school.
 
 In terms of the title, I saw a cartoon recently on the subject. It said something to the effect of "parents spend their whole lives wanting to make life better for their kids, then they complain that we are 'spoiled' when they succeed". Just thought that was kind of funny.
 
 On the general topic of kids being spoiled, it depends on the kid. Some kids are spoiled and some aren't. It's just the way parents are, they parent differently. Some parents let their kids sleep in and skip school if they're really tired (mostly seniors, but still). I went to school on time after I got back Sunday night at 2:30 AM. Now maybe it's just because I go to a generally poor school (over 50% on free and reduced lunch), but most kids today do not seem spoiled. The kids I know who have cars have one because they have jobs after school or else do sports (and some even do both, practice then a job, then homework).
Black Phoenix

I would say yes....as I leave adolescence and approach 20 I see now how spoiled I was..and I yet compared to kids today....I was deprived....which says a lot...
 
 School...my school would never close....we went to school during a huge blizzard I remember...when I was like in 2nd grade....we would go as long as power could turn on..and no water pipes exploded from the cold...
 
 In general.....I don't understand why a 12 year old needs a cell phone....or their own personal laptop.....or a flat screen tv in their room.....
 
 I thought having a family computer...an old piece of junk tv in my room...and one supernintendo, trampoline, above ground pool...and a fort....I was spoiled....oh and I didn't even get my first cell phone till was over 17....and I pay my own insurance, gas, and cell bill.....
 
 Now you have to have an ipod, laptop, PS2, Xbox, and Xbox 360, the 300$ Nextel phone and a plasma tv with the inground pool to be considered spoiled......wow
Jo Bennett

I'm not sure you can measure whether someone is spoiled solely by material goods, and certainly not solely by electronics, given the rate of advancement in that area over the last 20 years. I mean, an iPod today costs what a walkman did 20 years ago, a flatscreen TV costs what a CRT did 20 years ago. Whilst it's tempting to do the monty python yorkshire "luxury!" sketch, suffice to say that what kids get varies a great deal depending on their parents' finances and attitudes.
somnolence

Many states now have legislation banning employment of anyone under 16-yrs, lengthening dependency on full parental support. Liability concerns have removed opportunity for children and teens to pursue traditional money making pursuits such as gardening, lawn trimming, newspaper delivery, cleanup and other menial work. I'd think it would be difficult to instill a work ethic and the desire to advance one's self through education or learning a trade in someone beginning at age 16.

 
 Most kids still babysit, shovel walks for neighbors, pet-sit, and do other such small jobs for spending money. You don't have to be 16 to recognize the benefit of having your own income, and to pursue it.
somnolence

Children are being spoiled in being allowed to determine their own food intake. That's been happening for a long time, too.
 

 
 Oh please! What is wrong with that? How will you learn to recognize and follow your body's cues if you aren't ever allowed to pay attention to them? I was made to clean my plate as a kid, and I don't find it at all suprising that as an adult I often eat everything on my plate regardless of whether I'm already full or not. Those kinds of habits are hard to unlearn. I remember once going to Chili's and feeling full after only eating about a quarter of my food. I remember that I kept having this panicky feeling that I hadn't eaten enough of it and needed to eat more. Being made to eat all of my dinner has resulted in my often questioning my own satiety as an adult. It's not very healthy. 
 
 My daughter who is six is given free run of the kitchen, anything she can prepare herself anyway, and she eats much healthier than I usually do.
Aivlis

good point somnolence but that also goes the other way too. Some parents don't give their kids any kind of food intake direction whatsoever and let the kids eat whenever and whatever they want. We've all seen the 150 lb 5 year olds. Being spoiled has a lot to do with everything that a child demands and gets from their parents, either because the parents are lazy and do not want to instill values and respect or their want to buy their childs love.
somnolence
Unless they have some other physical problem, those kids are eating for reasons other than hunger, and they've been conditioned to do so. It's not a natural state.
Judeau

Unless they have some other physical problem, those kids are eating for reasons other than hunger, and they've been conditioned to do so. It's not a natural state.

 
 That's right. Part of being spoiled is the fact that they get what they want always. Like being conditioned to always get what you want. If you get what you want once, it doesn't mean that you are spoiled. But if you are 5 and weigh 150 lbs (10.66+ stones for the Brits on this forum) and do not have a medical condition, you are getting what you want when you want always, which to me sounds like being spoiled.
somnolence

Well, that's one way of looking at it. However 150 lb. 5 year olds are hardly the norm. Many parents allow their children to have control over what and how much they eat and have childen of healthy weights. Allowing this does not equal spoiling.
zachvac

good point somnolence but that also goes the other way too. Some parents don't give their kids any kind of food intake direction whatsoever and let the kids eat whenever and whatever they want. We've all seen the 150 lb 5 year olds. Being spoiled has a lot to do with everything that a child demands and gets from their parents, either because the parents are lazy and do not want to instill values and respect or their want to buy their childs love.

 
 Seriously? 150 lb FIVE year olds??? That's rediculous. I'm 17 and don't even weigh 140 lbs. But I think part of that problem is the parents also eat that horribly. If the parent puts their own body through that, what makes you think they'd care more for their kid's body? Hell I wouldn't even classify this as spoiling, it's harming the kid very much if they don't get the right nutrition. An otherwise healthy 5 year old does not weigh 150 lbs if they've been eating right. Of course I still can't even picture an 150 lb 5 year old. That's just insane.
georged

Seriously? 150 lb FIVE year olds??? That's rediculous. I'm 17 and don't even weigh 140 lbs. But I think part of that problem is the parents also eat that horribly. If the parent puts their own body through that, what makes you think they'd care more for their kid's body? Hell I wouldn't even classify this as spoiling, it's harming the kid very much if they don't get the right nutrition. An otherwise healthy 5 year old does not weigh 150 lbs if they've been eating right. Of course I still can't even picture an 150 lb 5 year old. That's just insane.

 
 They're referred to as Supersized Kids for obvious reasons. Eating fried, fast food a majority of the time will do it, as will a parent(s) who indulges a child's demands for foods high in calories. If one parent is overweight, a child stands an 80% chance of becoming obese with corresponding health problems early in life. 
 
 Some numbers:
 
 64.5 percent of U.S. adults, age 20 years and older, are overweight and 30.5 percent are obese.
 
 30% of children aged 2-5 are overweight (no breakdown on obesity). 
 
 Since children 2-5 seldom forage for their own food, guess who's to blame. 
 
 230lb 5-year old:
 
 http://www.squizzle.com/picview.asp?id=4628
Sheryl1970

good parents don`t allow their children the freedom of making their own choices and decisions until they are old enough to understand them. Letting your child become obese is shameful and a caring parent would intervene before it became such a big problem.Its every parents responsibility to guide their children through life.Instill in them the values and morals it takes to make it in the world.Be there for them to talk to and confide in without fearing snap judgments.The worst thing you can do to your child is try to be their friend instead of their parent !emoticon_xagree

Are children far too spoiled in this day and age? 

 Yes.
 In multiple ways, yes.
 From parents who defend their kids against the school punishment or home-work to giving the kids too many toys to allowing the kid to get fat on the couch instead of going out and doing something (childhood obesity problem) to ...
Penfold
I blame the people who give rights to zygotes. It leads to unrealistic expectations in childhood emoticon_xbouncer
QuackAttack1887

Oh, I most definitely am spoiled. So are the brothers I grew up with (someone I consider a brother moved in with us a few months ago). We don't do chores (some I can't do due to my asthma and allergies to chemicals and dust), my mom pays for my oldest brother (he's 27 and a drug addict so she thinks he's too sick to fend for himself) and his live in crazy girlfriend, who only pays rent and whines about how she's the only one who does that and how my brother figure doesn't but he works and spends his money on his debts, food, cigarettes, recreation and so on. Did I mention she's 31 and he's 18? 
 
 We were never disciplined as kids unless it was dad taking it too far and hitting his only daughter (me) when I was eight with all his strength. After that drama, my mom did the punishments, but no one followed through with them. At one point, I was getting detention on purpose so I wouldn't have to go home to my older brother and sick grandmother/protector, and more so after she died. I was told I was grounded for a month, and unless I had detention or doctors visits, I was to come straight home. The next day, I had rehersal, so I stayed home. It ran really late, and I got home last, and no one even remembered I was grounded. 
 
 So yeah, really spoiled. My mom takes me on trips for the 'important birthdays'. For example, when I turned 16, we went to NYC to see Les Miserables. Loved it so much. I watched a tape of the concert so often it broke.
 
 My family is now in debt.
Tommy Trying

Is it too much for an 11 year old to get a Gucci watch around $1000. She already has an iphone, laptop and flat screen in her room on the beach? She doesn't have too many friends and is an only child. She is not a show off but really likes grown up things and appreciates quality. I worked my XXX off in life like my parents my father who also helped me whenever he could (an orphan and the most honest person I know I am 41 and no skeletons in the closest, ever) to get here. I am debating with my wife who was brought up a missionary if I am going overboard and creating more problems for our future. Please, let me know. She is a great kid and for the most part always listens and respects us. My wife and I spend a lot of time with her and we are like best friends and in no way am I replacing material things for time spent together, lessons we will teach her the best we can. I think she is mature for her age as she has grown up in our business (hotels) and we never baby talked her. She communicates with staff and guests from all over the world like no one I've seen seen My wife thinks this maybe too much.
Ethmi
I don't have much to say except that I would've never gotten away with calling my mother a bitch like alot of kids do.

 I'd just say don't buy her alcohol or cigarettes, don't get her anything if she demands it, and try to punish bad behavior. You don't have to hit her, but don't let her get away with stuff, otherwise she'll take advantage of you.
jitobear

Kids are demanding little buggers and mine is no exception. We buy him some nice things (birthdays, Xmas) and I want him to have clothes he feels confident and attractive in (I did not and spent my whole childhood keenly aware and frequently reminded that I was ugly). We also travel a lot (usually road trips).
 
 However me and his dad made him get a job as soon as he was old enough to do so legally. He frequently buys his own clothes and toys (iPod), and he had to pay for half his trip to visit his best friend in LA last summer. Also he no longer is granted privileges. They are all earned - from TV watching to whether he will ever get to drive - its all laid out out in contract we all signed. 
 
 Still think he can be one spoiled little bugger. Maybe its simply the nature, to some degree, of a well loved child who feels safe? Push those limits!
Winston Smith

 It simply indentifies his responsibilities and what is earned when he carries them out. Having it written down like this keeps everyone accountable. I did not come up with the idea myself - a lot of resources on parenting teens suggested something like this.

It simply indentifies his responsibilities and what is earned when he carries them out. Having it written down like this keeps everyone accountable. I did not come up with the idea myself - a lot of resources on parenting teens suggested something like this.

 
 so if an idea that you accept and put in practice is not yours, then you are absolved of the responsibility if it doesn't work?
 
 A kind of carrot and stick arrangement enforced by 'law'. I suppose it is good training for some poor kid that will have grwo up to live in the land of the lawyers and the home of the litigious.
 
 Thanks God I don't live in the USA. We never treated our children like that, but, we are not Americans. Lucky for them

Today, I got a warning from Big Bros in regards to the above post. I was told to keep it friendly and informative or else.
 
 Since I didn't join this forum in search of friendship and I am never informative, it means I am doomed just like Antonia, although she at least was and is in her present incarnation informative.
 
 I was here just for the fun, for friendship I have my family, my dogs and flesh and bone friends of the kind you can share a beer with in our hot continent, "James Boag's" a Tasmanian lager being my present favourite.
 
 YouTube - James Boag Premium ad - keyhole emoticon_xhoho
 
 The more people are banned the poorer the forum, for it is almost always the most interesting people (I am the exception) who are banned.
 
 I don't mind being insulted, I have never reported anyone for I believe in free speech, and the moment free speech is subject to censorship it ceases to be free. For example I could submit to the Big Bros censorship and self-censor myself in order not to be banned. And all those reading my posts they would think my words were uncensored but, in reality they would not.
 I would know this and of course the Big Bros.
 
 Years ago when the then administrators put forward the idea of appointing a miriad of little Big Bros whom they called 'moderators' I strongly opposed the proposal which eventually was dropped, not because of my arguments of course
 
 Winston Smith my hero in "1984", was trapped he couldn't leave, he was arrested and brain washed.
 I instead, am free man, all I have to do is leave this forum right now and, this is what I will do unless the Big Bros decide, and this surely will happen, to ban me and erase this final post of mine.
 
 The last straw for me was the banning of Antonia, I realised then that this forum was not the place it used to be and this new place was not for me.
 So I continued behaving as a free man knowing my days were numbered.
 
 The Big Brothers will ban me and erase my last words, but not before reading them. That is good enough for me
 
 Adios y vayan todos con Dios, including baron and mae my sworn enemies. 
 
 emoticon_xbye
Symbiote

Free speech means you can say what you want on your own property, or on someone else's property with their permission.
 
 It means the law cannot restrict speech.
 
 There is no conflict between restricting speech on your own private forum and free speech as a general principle.
 
 In other words, you can't shout fire in a crowded theatre, unless you own the theatre, or the theatre owner gives you permission. Or in this case, if the forum owner wants to ban you, so be it. Personally I've had a few warnings in my time.
Winston Smith

A general principle is valid universally. Period
 
 what you are saying really, is that there is no free speech in this forum.
 
 I agree with the :
 
 "Or in this case, if the forum owner wants to ban you, so be it."
 
 So be it.
gansao

A general principle is valid universally. Period
 
 what you are saying really, is that there is no free speech in this forum.
 
 I agree with the :
 
 "Or in this case, if the forum owner wants to ban you, so be it."
 
 So be it.

 
 
 I thought you had gone.
Symbiote

A general principle is valid universally. Period

 
 That's correct. The most general principle at play is that of property rights. Free speech is an example of property rights. The forum owner has the property rights to this forum, so they, not the government, have control over who can say what on this forum.
 
 Just as you have the property rights to your body, so free speech means you, not the government, decide what to say.

 So I continued behaving as a free man knowing my days were numbered.

 Adios y vayan todos con Dios, including baron and mae my sworn enemies. 
 
 emoticon_xbye

 
 Yet another hairflip, Winston? You've got to hold the record for the most fake hairflips by now. I've witnessed at least a half dozen of them myself. emoticon_xbye
 
 Of course, you wion't really leave.....you never do. And don't worry about the Admin banning you for a single violation. I've had more than my share and I'm still here. ;)
Winston Smith

That's correct. The most general principle at play is that of property rights. Free speech is an example of property rights. The forum owner has the property rights to this forum, so they, not the government, have control over who can say what on this forum. 

 
 I don't see why the right to own property is according to you pre-eminent. Maybe because you see everything thru the crystal of Economics.
 
 IMHO rights are not God given but part of a social contract. The basic rights are: the right to life and liberty and lastly the right to property. I don't see what the right to property has to do with freedom of speech. You can in theory have no rights to own property but still have freedom of speech.
 There is no physical property involved in a forum. All it happens is that in this gathering place some people the Big Brothers can silence or expel (same thing) those they wish to silence.
 Property right is the right to usufruct not to curtail or grant freedom of speech to those entering the property. Do you warn your visitors that no freedom of speech is granted to those who enter your property?
 
 
 
 
 Just as you have the property rights to your body, so free speech means you, not the government, decide what to say.

 
 Property rights to my body? I am my body. Besides I don't have property rights to my body, because if the government decides to draft my body, what can I do ?
Symbiote
Since you believe people have the right to engage in social contract, please explain where this so-called right comes from? You probably think it comes from God, you religious nutjob, get a grip.
Winston Smith

It isn't pre-eminent. As you agreed, "A general principle is valid universally."
 
 A right isn't a right if sometimes a different right is "pre-eminent" and supercedes it. 

 
 Then it follows that the property right does not supercedes liberty (freedom of speech) 
 it also follows that not one right is more universal than another as you stated in your previous post: property right is more universal than freedom of speech. How can one universal be more universal than another. Illogical.
 
 
 
 
 
Spurious argument. You can't make a rightful contract unless you have a right to make a contract. If rights exist they necessarily precede society. I don't believe in god. God and social contract don't exhaust the available options, this is a false dichotomy.

 
 Wrong. If you are Robinson Crusoe you don't need rights or looking at it from your point of view he has all rights. if you live outside society then where are your rights? would you demand rights? from whom? from God? Rights are individuals rights inside a society. No society no rights. Period
 
 Rights do not precede society our needs precede society. A bill of right is a codification of what we consider the minimum protection as individuals from other individuals and from our rulers.
 
 
You can't make a rightful contract unless you have a right to make a contract
. 
 
 and to have a right to make a contract you need a previous right and so on and so on ... 
 
 Ridiculous, unless rights are assumed to be God given.
 
 We simply have a group of people who decide to enter in a social contract and the social contract has some clauses regarding the protection that indivuduals will have upon signing the contract, these protections are called human rights.
 What do you mean by saying that they need a 'right'? what do you mean by that, a letter of authorisation by a higher power, what ?
 
 I don't see how property rights can be extended to our own body, we are our own bodies. only rights to life, to freedom of movement, etc are pertinent to our own bodies not 'property rights' I went along with your bizarre extrapolation of property rights into the human body to show how absurd it is. 
 
 How ridiculous the statement "I have property rights over my body" sounds.
 Kind of crazy although maybe not to an economist.
Symbiote
Perhaps I'm the fool for arguing with someone who says they have no right to the use of their own body.
gansao

Yet another hairflip, Winston? You've got to hold the record for the most fake hairflips by now. I've witnessed at least a half dozen of them myself. emoticon_xbye
 
 Of course, you wion't really leave.....you never do. And don't worry about the Admin banning you for a single violation. I've had more than my share and I'm still here. ;)

 
 
 
 Looks like you were right.
JPSartre12

Looks like you were right.

 
 When it comes to one of Winston's hairflips, it's a gimme. ;)
Ethmi

A general principle is valid universally. Period
 
 what you are saying really, is that there is no free speech in this forum.
 
 I agree with the :
 
 "Or in this case, if the forum owner wants to ban you, so be it."
 
 So be it.

 
 Of course they can ban you. Honestly, I'm surprised you're still on here. You hate Americans like the KKK hates black people. Subaru was banned for the same thing, I believe.
Ethmi

I don't see why the right to own property is according to you pre-eminent. Maybe because you see everything thru the crystal of Economics.
 
 IMHO rights are not God given but part of a social contract. The basic rights are: the right to life and liberty and lastly the right to property. I don't see what the right to property has to do with freedom of speech. You can in theory have no rights to own property but still have freedom of speech.
 There is no physical property involved in a forum. All it happens is that in this gathering place some people the Big Brothers can silence or expel (same thing) those they wish to silence.
 Property right is the right to usufruct not to curtail or grant freedom of speech to those entering the property. Do you warn your visitors that no freedom of speech is granted to those who enter your property?

 
 Public property and private property are different. If I invite friends over to watch the superbowl and bring their friends who are complete strangers to me, I don't want somebody there handing out Neo-Nazi pamphlets. If somebody does and I don't like it, I have every right to tell them to leave, and if they refuse, then I can call the police and say I have an intruder. 
 
 In your private property, you can expel others from your property at will for any reason, or even for no reason. I say "Spread your hate all you want, just don't do it on my property." Even though anyone can join, this is not a public forum. Somewhere exists a person who created this website and presumabley pays a monthly fee for it to be hosted, just like you pay property taxes. That person owns this forum, and if he wanted to, he could legitimately come onto this forum, ban every single one of us for no reason, start posting his views, occasionally saying "So none of you have the backbone to discuss this with me?", and there wouldn't be a thing we could do about it, because it's his property and he would not be breaking any laws by doing that.
 
 
Property rights to my body? I am my body. Besides I don't have property rights to my body, because if the government decides to draft my body, what can I do ?

 
 That would be a government controlled state, where the government owns everything, including people. WOOT, YEAH, MORE BIG GOVERNMENT! MORE CZARS!

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Are children far too spoiled in this day and age?
